EDITED BY ROBIN AND ANNE McGREGOR 
Underlying the various options, suggestions, and proposals put 
forward by .contributors to this vitally important work is a set of major 
issues bedevilling attempts to resolve South Africa's continuing 
education ·crisis. 
It is these issues which threaten the viability of any strategy devised to 
create a democratic, non-racial and just education system. The same 
policies that brought about the present under-development of the 
education system have also crippled the economy. 
At a time when considerable resources are required to place education 
on a new path, the economy is just not in a position to provide them. 
This book is the first attempt to reconcile justified 
ideals and expectations with what is practically 
possible. 
It is only now that the debate has begun to penetrate the 
level of political negotiation. The setting up of the proposed 
Education Fonnn will increase the significance of the debate 
and hasten the resolution of the crisis. 
The purpose of McGREGOR'S EDUCATION 
ALTERNATIVES is to inform, influence and support 
decision makers, and to provide them with practical, 
realisable policy options. 
Foreword Ken Hartshorne Education System Change in South Africa Jane Hofmeyr & Peter Buckland

manufacture and distribution of gramophone 
records, tapes, video cassettes, music publishing 
and the provision of video production; manufacture 
and sale of greeting cards, stationery products 
and shop fittings and magazine distribution, and 
freighl forwarding & clearing. The company also 
has an interest in the M-Net television service.

COMPANY SECRETARY 
G D Knox 
NATURE OF BUSINESS 
The company operates three business divisions -
Sugar, Chemicals and Warehousing & Distribution. 
Sugar - Interest ranging from cane growing to 
milling,refining and packaging. Syrup Is also 
manufactured. Chemicals - The production of 
furfural,furfuryl alcohol,diacetyl and solvent 
from bagasse,ethyl alcohol,dlethyl ether,carbon 
dloxlde,vinegar,food yeast and hydrogen peroxide. 
The Warehousing & Distribution division handles 
and stores the bagged sugar production.

steel products to the mining & Industrial markets.

IN BUSINESS YOU SELDOM GET WHAT YOU DESERVE. 
YOU GET WHAT YOU NEGOTIATE. 
~ NEG iflATI N 
THEORIES, STRATEGIES & SKILLS 
By Wynand Pienaar & Manie Spoelstra 
... AND GET WHAT YOU DESERVE! 
Negotiation is a process involving many people on many levels, aimed at an 
agreement of mutual gain . No-one negotiates for loss or avoiding loss. 
Everyone shou ld negotiate for gain. The aim is always to look at common 
ground and the constant exploration of alternatives. We must do so within 
the context of informed judgment and under cond itions of timeously helping 
one another. This process requires flexibility, versati lity, and trust. 
NEGOTJAlJON

Aspects of negotiation covered by this book include: 
* Creating the right climate for negotiation * Relevant information and its presentation * Obtaining trust, visibility and flexibility * The influence of power, security and role * Changing perceptions and attitudes * Making decisions under conditions of uncertainty * Conflict resolution, and ... * The continuation of organisational success 
Because the price of conflict can only be paid 
afterwards, the price of peace must be paid 
beforehand. Whether in business or in politics, 
let's learn how to negotiate. 
THE MOST WIDELY USED AND LONGEST LASTING TRAINING 
COURSE ON NEGOTIATION FINALL Y AVAILABLE IN PRINT. 
PUBLISHED BY ~ JUTA & CO, LTD 
MCGREGOR'S 
COMPANY DISCLOSURE AND 
PROTECI'lON OF INVESTORS 
ON THEJSE 
For over four decades the country's rulers have insisted on determining 
what we should or should not know and this authoritarianism has spawned 
a similar attitude in the private sector. There is a noticeable reluctance by 
listed companies to share information with shareholders arid legislation 
embodied in the Companies Act of 1973 has made non-disclosure possible. 
AfriCaI\ nom\nee companies Why do so many South for secrecy's sake? 
appear to faVour secrecy hide their 
Why are large pension funds opting to 
investments? 
TO WHAT END? the xtent of their power 
'S it that they want to hide e 
or wealth? ----Iblllty in the event of 
Do they want to evade 'r .... an inVestment golng sou told that management 
Or are Investors simply being 
may do as it pleases? 
In this incisive work, Professor Narendra Bhana has critically examined 
many of the regulations in the Companies Act and the Generally Accepted 
Accounting Practices and he has made recommendations which both remove 
ambiguities and bear the interests of shareholders in mind. He makes the 
point that ' ... the more information investors have at their disposal, 
especially with respect to future prospects, the lower the perceived risk, and 
the higher they would set the company's per share price. Therefore, it is in 
the company's interest to make the fullest disclosure possible.' 
THIS BOOK IS ESSENTIAL READING FOR ANYBODY IN BUSINESS IN SOUTH AFRICA TODAY. 
Hard Cover • R75,90 inc VAT • Available from leading booksellers countrywide

Marketing of fuels, lubricants and other petroleum 
products; Production by way of petroleum refining, 
the ability to produce various chemical feedstocks 
and a 30% interest In Mossgas; Exploration

Soekor.

NATURE OF BUSINESS 
Group activities Include the following: 
Manufacture & distribution of power transmission 
products, PVC conveyor belting, hydraulic gear 
pumps & valves, moulded rubber products, slurry 
submersible & centrifugal pumps, control valves 
& systems, grey Iron & SG castings, rubber wear 
protection, screening & dust sealing products. 
The group also offers on-Site machining, valve 
repair & leak sealing services.

NATURE OF BUSINESS

872 pages 
R145 00 inc VAT 
Written in an easy-to-read, conversational style and placed within the context of 
ten different organisational prototypes, the more than 100 cases may be used for 
individual reading (as a book), or for training practitioners and 'students in the 
essential principles of industrial relations, human resource management and 
organisational development. The latter half of this text which runs to 672 pages is 
devoted to discussions on each case. These supply pOinters to the correct 
handling of each situation and to the interactional dynamics contained therein. 
PUBLISHED BY JUrA & CO, LTD 
Gencor controls quoted Sappl, Trans-Natal Coat, 
Engen, Impala Platinum, Genbel & Malhold.

mild steel chain & Wire, wire JOining products, 
copper & brass extrusions, copper & allOY rolled 
products Incl Ingots, tube & castings, cutting 
tools, reamers, taps & dies, steellWlst drills, 
saw blades, rivets & rivet tools The group also 
operates a waste disposal bUSiness

NATURE OF BUSINESS 
The group Is engaged In the manufacture and 
distribution of leather and canvas goods and 
outdoor equipment and furniture. The main 
products produced are harnesses, saddlery, 
camping and back-packing products, as well 
as outdoor and kitchen furniture. Leasing 
facilities are also provided for the Group 
requirements as well as non-Group customers.

HJ Gaylard - Implats Cons & Man Serv (Ply) LId 
NATURE OF BUSINESS 
The group mines, processes, refines & markets 
platinum. The lease area Is situated In the 
Bafokeng district of Bophuthatswana, and four 
mines are operated. In addition to platinum, 
Impala produces palladium, rhodium, ruthenium, 
Iridium, gold, silver, nickel, copper & cobalt. 
Ammonium sulphate & sulphuric acid are produced 
as by-products of the metallurgical processes. 
The company holds a contrOlling Interest In 
quoted Barplats Investments Ltd & Messina Ltd.

NATURE OF BUSINESS 
JOHNSON&FLETCHER Is Incorporated In Zimbabwe with 
a 92% locally owned capital base. The trading division sells building malerials,particUlarlY,tlmber 
tools,hardware and sanllaryware.Produclion division manufactures stock and purpose made joinery 
as well as specialising In hardwood doors. Gangnail roof trusses are deSigned and fabricated at 
three strategically placed truss plants.

COMPANY SECRETARY 
D Jones 
NATURE OF BUSINESS 
The group manufactures raw materials for use In 
the detergent & tOiletry Industries, as well as 
general chemical applications, which Include: 
Supply of aromatic sulphonic acids; Supply of 
defoamers and dispersants to the pulp and paper 
manufacturing Industries, processing chemicals 
for textile applications and emulsion polymers 
for carpet backing applications & surface coatings 
Manufacture of metalliC driers, chemical salts, 
fire retardent & timber preservation chemicals.

The company holds a contrOlling Interest in Marlin 
Corporation, which is also quoted on the JSE. 
Marlin Corporation quarries black, dark grey, pink 
green & yellow granite In the Belfast, Rustenburg, 
, Parys, Namaqualand and Walvis Bay areas. Most 
production is exported to Europe, N America & the 
Far East.

An Investment holding company, receiving Income 
In the form of dividends from Its wholly owned 
subsidiary, which Is the owner of rental Income 
producing commercial and Industrial properties, 
and parking garages, mainly In Durban, Pinetown 
and cape Town. The SUbsidiary also operates a 
confirming & Indent financing division, a motor

NATURE OF BUSINESS 
A retail motor organisation. The Group retails 
particular new vehicle franchises & used vehicles, 
together with the attendant sales of accessories, 
477 
parts & service, and Imports & distributes motor 
cycles, industrial engines, generators, outboard 
motors, marine accessories & boats. Activities

leasing and auctioning of motor vehicles. The 
group also has extensive property Interests, which 
are leased to its trading divisions.

EDITED BY ROBIN AND ANNE McGREGOR 
Underlying the various options, suggestions, and proposals put 
forward by .contributors to this vitally important work is a set of major 
issues bedevilling attempts to resolve South Africa's continuing 
education crisis. 
It is these issues which threaten the viability of any strategy devised to 
create a democratic, non-racial and just education system. The same 
policies that brought about the present under-development of the 
education system have also crippled the economy. 
At a time when considerable resources are required to place education 
on a new path, the economy is just not in a position to provide them. 
This book is the first attempt to reconcile justified 
ideals and expectations with what is practically 
possible. 
It is only now that the debate has begun to penetrate the 
level of political negotiation. The setting up of the proposed 
Education Fonun will increase the significance of the debate 
and hasten the resolution of the crisis. 
The purpose of McGREGOR'S EDUCATION 
ALTERNATIVES is to inform, influence and support 
decision makers, and to provide them with practical, 
realisable pOlicy options. 
Foreword Ken Hartshorne Education System Change in South AIrlca Jane Hofmeyr & Peter Buckland

Cosatu Human Resources Committee The ANC View John Samuel Education & Training in the New South 
Africa: The Needs and Responsibilities of Busine .. Bobby Godseliinitial Teacher Education 
Rob Sieborger & Alan Kenyon The Challenge of Inset in the 1990s Jane Hofmeyr & Rosamund Jaff 
South African Farm Schools: Children in the Shadow Johann Graaff & Adele Gordon Early

Donaldson PrIvate and Alternative Schools Johan Muller Technical and HH:ational Education

MCGREGOR'S 
COMPANY DISCLOSURE AND 
PROTECTION OF INVESTORS 
ONTHEJSE 
For over four decades the country's rulers have insisted on determining 
what we should or should not know and this authoritarianism has spawned 
a similar attitude in the private sector. There is a noticeable reluctance by 
listed companies to share information with shareholders arid legislation 
embodied in the Companies Act of 1973 has made non-disclosure possible. 
South African nominee companies Why do so many fof secrecy's sake? 
appear to tavour secrecy opting to hide their 
Why are large pension funds 
Investments? ? 
TO WHAT END. the xtent of their power 
Is it that they want to hide e 
or wealth? ----lblt!ty \n the event of 
Do they want to evade 7-
an inWstment golng sou told that management. 
Or are Investors simply being 
may do as it pteases? 
In this incisive work, Professor Narendra Bhana has critically examined 
many of the regulations in the Companies Act and the Generally Accepted 
Accounting Practices and he has made recommendations which both remove 
ambiguities and bear the interests of shareholders in mind. He makes the 
point that ' ... the more information investors have at their disposal, 
especially with respect to future prospects, the lower the perceived risk, and 
the higher they would set the company's per share price. Therefore, it is in 
the company's interest to make the fullest disclosure possible.' 
THIS BOOK IS ESSENTIAL READING FOR ANYBODY IN BUSINESS IN SOUTH AFRICA TODAY. 
Hard Cover • R75,90 Inc VAT • Available from leading booksellers countrywide

NATURE OF BUSINESS 
MIDMACOR Is comprised of two main divisions: 
The Industrial division comprises sole agency for 
HONDA products, franchise and agency for MILLER 
welding equipment,CEM welders, VM diesel engines 
DARI and Boge compressors. The leisure division 
holds the SA franchise for HONDA motorcycles and 
Is a large distributor of motorcycle accessories.

NATURE OF BUSINESS 
The company operates three major mines which 
explollthe platinum-bearing ores of the 
Bushveld Igneous Complex.The primary product of 
the group Is platinum; other metats recovered are 
palladium, rhodium, Iridium, ruthenium, osmium, 
gOld, sliver, copper, and nickel. Cobalt sulphate, 
sulphuric acid and sodium sulphate are also 
produced.

NATURE OF BUSINESS 
Sappl IS a vertically Integrated forests products 
company, With core business being beneficiation of 
natural wood fibres Into a vanety of products, 
Including unbleached and bleached pulp, dissolving 
pUlp, newspnnt, Ilnerboard, cast coated papers, 
corrugating medium, stationery paper, carbon less 
copy paper, structural & mining timber, coated art 
label paper, sackkraft and other kraft packaging 
papers, fibreboard, particle and laminated board 
and chemical by-products

NATURE OF BUSINESS 
The main business ot the company Is mining & 
exploration for precious stones & metals, base 
minerals, ferrous & non-ferrous metals, coal & 
allied minerals and turning to account ot Its 
minerai Interests. In terms of area, approx 50% of 
the company's prospects are gold based, 30% have 
coal and base minerai potential, and the remaining 
20% are orientated towards diamonds and platinum 
group metals.

NATURE OF BUSINESS 
The activities of the group are as follows: 
Sugar milling, refining & farming; Production of 
clay face, paving & plaster brICks & blOCks, tiles 
& concrete brICks; Food processing, producing 
mushrooms, edible oils, animal feeds, maize meal, 
dehydraJed foodstuffs & eggs, conon ginning, 
Industrial & commercial catering; Manufacture of 
aluminium products; Textile mills which produce 
knlnlng & weaving yarns & fabrics; Production of 
speciality starches & syrups & malzegerm.
